I found the method call I was looking for. The MockEJB framework has
an EjbBeanAccess interface that you can cast your proxy to in order to
get a reference to the actual bean. Thanx all.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "cliftonccraig" <cliftonccraig@y...> wrote:
> Alright I'm in the thick of EJB mocking now and having some troubles.
> Using mockEJB I'm able to mock an EJB container deployment and
> retreive my EJB frmo the mock container. The problem is that I'm
> having difficulties accessing protected members of my EJB. Example: I
> have a session bean that I'm unit testing and I want to test a
> protected method but it appears that I can only access the bean
> through the remote interface. Does this mean I have to define all of
> the protected members in the remote interface so my test can access
> them? The problem that appears is when you lookup the session bean.
> You get a reference to the home interface and call create on that
> interface. This returns a proxy to your bean and the proxy only
> implements the remote interface. I need direct access to my bean to
> get a good unit test. Is this possible? Am I doing something wrong?
> 
> Cliff 
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "cliftonccraig" <cliftonccraig@y...>
wrote:
> > J.B.,
> > 
> > Thanx for the advice. I am trying mockEJB and it seems pretty straight
> > foward. I'll let you know how it goes. Thanx.
> > 
> > Cliff
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> > > cliftonccraig wrote:
> > > 
> > > > Alright, I've been "test infected" for a little while now and I'm
> > > > writing my tests before writing any implementation logic. Now
I need
> > > > to modify some existing EJBs which have not yet been touched
> with the
> > > > test infection. Where do I start? We are nearing our beta date
> and we
> > > > cannot afford any major upsets in the existing code base. I feel
> like
> > > > I cannot continue my current project until I write a test of
> some sort
> > > > for this session bean. I don't want to have to write an
integration
> > > > test first. I've been hearing that cactus is the thing for me
but I
> > > > cannot get a good mental picture of how to start with it or how it
> > > > works. If I use Cactus does that mean that I have to deploy my
> entire
> > > > app before testing the EJB? Please help.
> > > 
> > > Short answers:
> > > 
> > > 1. You can test the EJB in Cactus by just deploying the EJB. Your
> > Cactus 
> > > test simply uses the EJB. No need to deploy the entire application.
> > > 
> > > 2. Session beans are easy to make testable, compared to entity
beans. 
> > > You can make some mechanical code changes and test 99% of the
session 
> > > bean's logic /without/ a container!
> > > 
> > > 3. You can also try MockEJB (www.mockejb.org). In fact, if I were
> > you, I 
> > > might start here.
> > > 
> > > Finally--you guessed it--read chapter 11 of _JUnit Recipes_, which 
> > > covers testing EJBs in about 75 pages. (www.manning.com/rainsberger)
> > > 
> > > Good luck.
